description: A pot-like helmet dating back to the dark days of the first world war, the Brodie helmet (actually known as the Helmet, Steel, Mark I) was one of the first steel helmets to see use in modern warfare. It is derived from a relatively simple construction process, high hardness steel being stamped into a vague pot-like shape. Generally considered to be lacking in coverage compared to later helmets in America, Europe and Russia.

An iconic steel helmet developed by the Soviet Union in 1968. Saw use until the Union's final days and is still seen in many a third-world army. Doesn't provide as much protection as modern helmets but is still decent.
